newsitem.title: USA: Clinton says no decision yet on Helms-Burton.
newsitem.headline: Clinton says no decision yet on Helms-Burton.

text.p: U.S. President Bill Clinton said Monday he had not made a final decision on implementing part of an anti-Cuban law that had angered America's European allies that do business on the island.

"That decision will be made some time in the middle of next month," Clinton said of implementing the U.S. Helms-Burton law. He spoke at a joint news conference with European Commisssion President Jacques Santer and Prime Minister John Bruton of Ireland, which holds the rotating European Union presidency.
The Helms-Burton law, passed by Congress last winter, infuriated some U.S. allies by threatening actions against foreign firms that do certain kinds of business on Cuba.

After the law was passed Clinton suspended for six months the right it granted to U.S. companies and individuals to file suits against foreigners who do business with assets in Cuba expropriated from Americans. The president now must decide whether to go ahead with implementing the law.

Santer said his talks with Clinton had helped to "clear the air" on Cuba and that they agreed on the end goal of democracy there. But he added: "Europe will remain firmly opposed to all extra-territorial legislation, whatever its source." He added that the EU was sticking with its decision to pursue the issue at the World Trade Organisation.
Clinton hailed a pledge last Saturday by European Union leaders to push for democracy in Cuba.
